name: Mahabodhi Temple
shortDescription: The most sacred site in Buddhism where Prince Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment under the Bodhi Tree in Bodh Gaya, India (c. 528 BCE)
fullDescription: The Mahabodhi Temple marks the most sacred site in Buddhism‚Äîthe location where Prince Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment and became the Buddha approximately 2,500 years ago (c. 528 BCE). The temple complex stands beside the Bodhi Tree, a direct descendant of the original tree under which the Buddha meditated for 49 days before achieving nirvana. The current temple structure, a 55-meter tall pyramid-shaped tower built entirely of brick, dates from the 5th-6th century CE during the late Gupta period, making it one of the earliest and most significant brick temples to survive from ancient India. The site includes the sacred Bodhi Tree, the Vajrasana (Diamond Throne) marking the exact spot of enlightenment, meditation platforms commemorating the seven weeks following enlightenment, and numerous votive stupas erected by pilgrims over centuries. Emperor Ashoka established the first shrine here c. 260 BCE. The temple has witnessed Buddhism's full arc in India‚Äîfrom its golden age through centuries of decline following Muslim invasions to its 19th-century rediscovery and restoration. UNESCO designated the complex a World Heritage Site in 2002. For over two millennia, pilgrims from across Asia have traveled to this spot, making it the most important pilgrimage destination in Buddhism, revered equally by Theravada, Mahayana, and Vajrayana traditions.

geography.location: Bodh Gaya, Bihar, India (13 km from Gaya)

inhabitants.name: Gautama Buddha
inhabitants.description: Prince Siddhartha who achieved supreme enlightenment at this exact location, founding Buddhism

inhabitants.name: Mara
inhabitants.description: Demon king who attempted to prevent Buddha's enlightenment through temptation and fear

inhabitants.name: Earth Goddess (Sthavara)
inhabitants.description: Witnessed Buddha's worthiness when he touched the ground, defeating Mara's challenge

inhabitants.name: Mucalinda Naga King
inhabitants.description: Serpent king who sheltered Buddha from storm with his hood during meditation week

events.name: Buddha's Enlightenment (c. 528 BCE)
events.description: Prince Siddhartha Gautama meditates under the Bodhi Tree for 49 days, overcomes temptations of Mara, touches earth to witness his worthiness, and achieves supreme enlightenment at dawn, discovering the Four Noble Truths and becoming the Buddha

events.name: Seven Weeks Following Enlightenment (c. 528 BCE)
events.description: Buddha remains at the site for seven weeks, each marked by different activities: gazing unblinkingly at the tree, walking meditation creating jeweled lotuses, meditating in jewel house, visited by Brahma Sahampati, sheltered from storm by Mucalinda

events.name: Ashoka's Visit and First Shrine (c. 260 BCE)
events.description: Emperor Ashoka visits the site, establishes first substantial shrine, erects the Vajrasana (Diamond Throne) marking exact spot of enlightenment, begins tradition of imperial patronage

events.name: Construction of Current Temple (5th-6th century CE)
events.description: During late Gupta period, current brick temple structure built in distinctive pyramid style that influenced Buddhist architecture across Asia

events.name: Xuanzang's Visit (7th century CE)
events.description: Chinese monk-scholar Xuanzang visits and provides detailed description of temple and monastic complex in his travel records

events.name: Muslim Invasions and Decline (12th-13th century)
events.description: Temple damaged during Muslim invasions; Buddhism declines in India, site falls into neglect though never completely abandoned

events.name: Rediscovery (1811)
events.description: British archaeologist Francis Buchanan-Hamilton rediscovers temple, bringing it to Western scholarly attention

events.name: Major Restoration (1861-1880)
events.description: Archaeological Survey of India under Alexander Cunningham conducts comprehensive restoration, repairing structure and documenting site

events.name: Ambedkar's Mass Conversion (1956)
events.description: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar leads mass conversion of Dalits to Buddhism at this site, revitalizing Buddhism in India

events.name: UNESCO World Heritage Designation (2002)
events.description: Mahabodhi Temple Complex designated UNESCO World Heritage Site for outstanding universal value

events.name: Terrorist Attack (2013)
events.description: Bomb attack damages temple complex; subsequently repaired with enhanced security measures

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Mahabodhi Temple represents the axis mundi of Buddhism‚Äîthe cosmic center where the spiritual breakthrough of the Buddha radiated outward to illuminate the world. The Vajrasana (Diamond Throne) marks the 'navel of the earth' in Buddhist cosmology, believed to be the immovable spot throughout cosmic cycles where all Buddhas of past, present, and future achieve enlightenment. The Bodhi Tree symbolizes the living connection to Buddha's awakening‚Äîa direct botanical descendant linking present pilgrims to that transformative moment 2,500 years ago. The temple's pyramid structure represents the upward journey toward enlightenment. The seven locations commemorating Buddha's seven weeks after enlightenment map a sacred geography of meditation, contemplation, and spiritual consolidation. The site embodies the possibility of human transformation from ignorance to perfect wisdom.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Mahabodhi Temple is the holiest site in Buddhism, surpassing even Buddha's birthplace (Lumbini), first sermon site (Sarnath), and death location (Kushinagar). All Buddhist traditions‚ÄîTheravada, Mahayana, and Vajrayana‚Äîequally revere the site, making pilgrimage here a life goal for devout Buddhists worldwide. Merit gained by pilgrimage is considered immense. The temple influenced Buddhist architectural styles across Asia, from Sri Lanka to Tibet to Japan. The Bodhi Tree's descendants have been planted at Buddhist sites globally, spreading the sacred lineage. Modern international monasteries surrounding the complex (Thai, Tibetan, Japanese, Bhutanese, etc.) demonstrate Buddhism's global reach. The site symbolizes both Buddhism's Indian origins and its transcendence of geographic and sectarian boundaries. Contemporary challenges include balancing Hindu-Buddhist joint management, mass tourism impact, and security concerns.

mythologyContexts.usage: Supreme pilgrimage site; source of Bodhi Tree lineage to Sri Lanka (288 BCE); emphasis on historical Buddha's enlightenment; meditation practice at exact spot
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Theravada tradition emphasizes the historical authenticity of the enlightenment event and the physical connection through the Bodhi Tree lineage. King Ashoka's daughter Sanghamitta took a cutting of the original tree to Sri Lanka in 288 BCE, where it still grows at Anuradhapura‚Äîthe oldest historically documented tree in the world.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Theravada Buddhists from Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Thailand, and Cambodia make pilgrimage to reconnect with Buddhism's historical origins. The site validates Theravada's emphasis on the historical Buddha rather than cosmic Buddhas.

mythologyContexts.usage: Cosmic significance beyond historical event; site where bodhisattva ideal was perfected; Sudhana's pilgrimage in Gandavyuha Sutra parallels journey to Bodh Gaya
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Mahayana tradition sees Bodh Gaya as the cosmic center where Buddha's enlightenment represents the culmination of countless previous lives as a bodhisattva. The site symbolizes the universal possibility of enlightenment for all beings.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese Buddhists view pilgrimage to Bodh Gaya as following the path of ancient masters like Xuanzang and Faxian. The site inspired Mahayana art and architecture throughout East Asia.

mythologyContexts.usage: Tantric practice site; Vajrasana as indestructible diamond seat; location where Nagarjuna, Aryadeva, Asanga, and Atisha studied and received teachings
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Vajrayana emphasizes the tantric significance of Bodh Gaya as a power place where the subtle energies of earth converge. The Vajrasana represents the indestructible nature of enlightened mind. Meditating at the exact spot is believed to accelerate spiritual realization.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Tibetan Buddhists perform extensive prostrations around the temple‚Äîthousands of full-body prostrations circumambulating the complex as profound purification practice. The site is particularly sacred to Gelug, Kagyu, Nyingma, and Sakya schools. Many Tibetan teachers have received visions and teachings at Bodh Gaya.

originPoint.name: Mahabodhi Temple Complex, Bodh Gaya, Bihar, India
originPoint.description: Located in Bodh Gaya, Bihar, India, 13 km from Gaya city. Temple complex encompasses 4.86 hectares. Temple height: 55 meters. Elevation approximately 115 meters above sea level. Located on the banks of Niranjana River (also called Phalgu River).

firstAttestation.description: Buddha's enlightenment traditionally dated to c. 528 BCE (some scholars prefer c. 563-483 BCE or c. 480-400 BCE). First physical monument established by Emperor Ashoka c. 260 BCE with erection of Vajrasana and initial shrine. Current temple structure dates to 5th-6th century CE (late Gupta period).
firstAttestation.source: Buddhist textual tradition, Ashokan inscriptions, architectural analysis of current structure

timelinePosition.context: The site has been continuously sacred for over 2,500 years, from Buddha's enlightenment through Ashokan imperial patronage, Gupta temple construction, medieval decline, colonial rediscovery, and modern Buddhist revival. It represents the geographic foundation of Buddhism as a world religion.
